gen.metadata.title: High-gain patch antenna for cubesat-based automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast application
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a miniaturized high-gain antenna suitable for hosting into a cubesat for ADS-B operation (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve a compact size and low-profile structure (p. 1); Ensure sufficient bandwidth and good gain over the operating band for ADS-B receiver (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate further improvements in radiation efficiency at higher frequencies (p. 3)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the proposed antenna design for cubesat-based ADS-B applications (p. 3)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing a compact and high-gain antenna for cubesat-based ADS-B operation is challenging (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a compact and high-gain antenna be designed for cubesat-based ADS-B operation? (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The proposed antenna has a compact size and high gain, making it suitable for cubesat-based ADS-B operation (p. 3)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Directional with a −3 dB aperture (beamwidth) of about 85-90° (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_siz: 0.29 λ0 × 0.29λ0 × 0.03λ0 in electrical length at 1.090 GHz (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Stacked-patch antenna with slots and reflectors (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Probe feed at location 18 mm from the center in the x-direction (p. 2)

gen.metadata.authors: Abd-Elmonieum, S. I.; Elkamchouchi, H. M.; Madany, Y. M.
gen.metadata.title: High-Gain Pixel Patch Antenna Array for Miniature Wireless Communications and IoT Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To investigate pixel antenna arrays for wireless communication and IoT systems, focusing on design, analysis, and comparison with traditional designs (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve a 75% reduction in patch design area and a 90% reduction in full design area (p. 14); Design and analyze pixel patch antennas for 5G and CubeSat applications (p. 1); Compare the performance of traditional and proposed pixel patch antennas (p. 1); Evaluate the performance of the proposed pixel antenna array in terms of gain and radiation pattern (p. 14)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigation of the proposed design in real-world 5G and CubeSat applications (p. 6); Investigate the performance of the proposed design in different environments and applications (p. 14)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the proposed pixel antenna design in small space devices and miniaturized systems (p. 14); Further testing and optimization of the proposed design for different frequency bands (p. 6)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for small, high-gain, and efficient antennas for 5G and CubeSat applications due to the rapid development of wireless technology and the downsizing of devices and satellites (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can the proposed pixel antenna design achieve miniaturization and high gain? (p. 14); How can pixel patch antennas be designed to meet the functional requirements for 5G and CubeSat applications? (p. 1); What are the performance improvements of the proposed pixel antenna compared to traditional designs? (p. 14); What are the performance metrics and design parameters of pixel patch antennas compared to traditional designs? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: Network analyzer for measuring traditional patch antenna and proposed pixel patch element structures (p. 14)
esp.domain_methodology.performance_metri: Gain, radiation pattern, design area reduction (p. 14)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Finite element method (FEM) and commercial software (Altair FEKO) (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The proposed pixel patch design area reduction is approximately 75%, and the full design area reduction is approximately 90% (p. 14)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers Duroid 6010 (εr = 10.2, tan δ = 0.0023, h = 0.635 mm) (p. 3)

gen.metadata.authors: Sayeed Sajal; Saeed I. Latif; Edmund Spencer
gen.metadata.title: Circularly Polarized Small-Footprint Hybrid Ring-Patch Stacked Antenna For Pico-Satellites
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a CP patch antenna that can be accommodated on the top plate of a cubesat for communicating with high-orbital satellite networks (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve wide impedance and beamwidth from a stacked patch-ring configuration on a small ground plane (p. 1); Optimize the antenna parameters for cubesat applications (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: An optimized design will be fabricated and tested to confirm simulations, and results will be presented at the symposium (p. 2)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Further optimization of the antenna will be conducted on a metallic cubesat structure (p. 2)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing a small-footprint wideband, wide beamwidth circularly polarized (CP) hybrid stacked patch-ring microstrip antenna for cubesat applications (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a wide axial ratio bandwidth and beamwidth be achieved from a singly-fed microstrip antenna with a small footprint? (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Wide 3-dB axial ratio beamwidth is significantly larger than that with a single-layer CP patch antenna (p. 2)

gen.metadata.authors: Mengu Cho; Hyosuk Kim; Hyunseung Moon; Yoonyoung Ko; Mohammad Tariqul Islam; M. Samsuzzaman; Salehin Kibria; Youngchul Chung
gen.metadata.title: A Compact Circularly Polarized High Gain S-Band Nanosatellite Antenna Using Ramped Convergence Particle Swarm Optimization
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design, fabricate, and characterize a variable optical delay device composed of double ring add/drop filters and delay waveguides (p. 1508)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Optimize the antenna using the ramped convergence particle swarm optimization (RCPSO) algorithm (p. 2); Fine adjustment of time delay through cascaded all-pass filters (p. 1508); Achieve the required S-band impedance bandwidth, 3 dB AR beamwidth, and high gain (p. 1); Achieve discretely variable time delay through delay waveguides (p. 1508)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Further optimization and testing of the antenna for other small satellite applications (p. 5); Investigation of the device's performance in real-world applications (p. 1508)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Further development and integration of the device into all-optical packet networks (p. 1508); Use the optimized antenna design for HORYU-IV nanosatellite S-band communication (p. 5)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for a compact, high-gain, circularly polarized patch antenna for HORYU-IV nanosatellite S-band communication to improve received signal power and reliability (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can the performance of a compact, high-gain, circularly polarized patch antenna be optimized for HORYU-IV nanosatellite S-band communication? (p. 1); What are the specific design parameters and optimization techniques required to meet the HORYU-IV antenna specifications? (p. 1); How can variable optical delay devices be designed and fabricated to support all-optical packet networks? (p. 1508)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: RCPSO algorithm with IE3D and Altair FEKO (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Compact single layer coaxial probe fed circularly polarized high gain patch antenna (p. 1)

gen.metadata.authors: SALEHIN KIBRIA; MD. SAMSUZZAMAN; M. T. Islam; S. Kibria; MENGU CHO; Mengu Cho; M. Cho; Mohammad Tariqul Islam; M. Samsuzzaman; Salehin Kibria; MOHAMMAD TARIQUL ISLAM
gen.metadata.title: BIRDS-1 CubeSat Constellation Using Compact UHF Patch Antenna
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and test a compact UHF band patch antenna for the BIRDS-1 CubeSat constellation (p. 6)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Integrate and test the antenna with the 1U BIRDS-1 satellite (p. 1); Ensure the antenna is lightweight and mechanically robust (p. 1); Achieve a compact size, low profile, and geometric characteristics (p. 6); Achieve a compact antenna dimension suitable for 1U CubeSat (p. 1); Integrate and test the antenna with the BIRDS-1 satellite body (p. 6); Not mentioned; Ensure good impedance matching and radiation pattern (p. 6)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the performance of the antenna in different environmental conditions (p. 1); Explore the use of the UHF antenna in other small satellite applications (p. 11); Not mentioned; Explore further miniaturization techniques for UHF patch antennas (p. 1); Investigate the performance of the UHF antenna in different orbital environments (p. 11)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integrate the UHF antenna into future CubeSat missions (p. 11); Perform additional environmental tests to ensure long-term reliability (p. 11); Integrate the antenna with other CubeSat components to ensure compatibility (p. 1); Not mentioned; Use the proposed antenna design for future 1U CubeSat missions (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing a compact and efficient UHF patch antenna for 1U CubeSats due to the limited surface area and the need for reliable communication (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a compact UHF band patch antenna be designed for 1U CubeSat missions? (p. 6); How can a compact UHF patch antenna be designed to fit within the limited space of a 1U CubeSat? (p. 1); What are the performance characteristics of the proposed UHF patch antenna? (p. 1); Not mentioned; What are the performance metrics of the proposed UHF antenna compared to existing designs? (p. 6)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: Agilent N5227A PNA microwave network analyzer (p. 5)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Finite element method (FEM) and Method of Momentum (MoM) (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms other designs in terms of size, gain, and radiation pattern (p. 6)
esp.domain_results.gain: 0.55 dB realized gain, 1.01 dB peak gain (p. 6)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Folded meander line patch, shorting pin, and partial ground plane with coaxial probe fed (p. 6)

gen.metadata.authors: Gilda Priscila; Putri Indra Wahyuningsih; Levy Olivia Nur; Amanda Nurul Islam Ali; Edwar
gen.metadata.title: Microstrip Antenna Gain Enhancement using Multilayer Substrate and Superstrate Structure for Space-Based ADS-B Surveillance
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and optimize a high gain microstrip antenna for CubeSat applications using a multilayer substrate and superstrate structure (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Evaluate the performance of the initial microstrip antenna design (p. 2); Optimize the antenna design by adding a superstrate layer and increasing the substrate thickness (p. 2); Fabricate and measure the performance of the optimized antenna (p. 2); Increase the antenna gain (p. 7); Improve the return loss and bandwidth (p. 7); Maintain a compact form factor (p. 7)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigation of other superstrate designs for further gain improvement (p. 6); Long-term reliability testing of the antenna in space conditions (p. 6); Investigation of other superstrate designs and materials (p. 7)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integration of the antenna into CubeSat systems for real-world testing (p. 6); Further optimization of the antenna design for better performance (p. 6); Further optimization of the antenna design for better performance (p. 7)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for a high gain antenna for space-based ADS-B surveillance to cover remote areas where ground-based systems are insufficient (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What is the impact of using a multilayer substrate and superstrate structure on the antenna's performance? (p. 1); How can the gain and bandwidth of an ADS-B antenna be improved for CubeSat applications? (p. 7); How can the gain of a microstrip antenna be enhanced for CubeSat applications? (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms previous works in gain performance (p. 6)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_siz: Fits within the Z-axis side of a 1U CubeSat (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Microstrip patch antenna with superstrate and additional substrate layer (p. 7)
esp.technical_specifications.superstrate: Circular patch identical to the microstrip antenna patch (p. 3)

gen.metadata.authors: Fawzy Ibrahim; Hadia El-Henawy; Rabie, M.M.; El-Hefnawy, F.; Ibrahim, F.; El-Henawy, H.; Fatma El-Hefnawy; Mostafa Mahmoud Rabie
gen.metadata.title: Meshed Conductor and Meshed Substrate GPS L1 Band Microstrip Antenna for Cubesat Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design, simulate, and fabricate a transparent meshed conductor and meshed substrate circularly polarized GPS L1 band microstrip antenna for Cubesat applications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Meet desired specifications for S11 parameter, antenna gain, bandwidth, and transparency (p. 8); Achieve circular polarization with RHCP (p. 8); Achieve a resonance frequency of 1.575 GHz (p. 3); Achieve a percentage of transparency of at least 60% (p. 3); Achieve an antenna efficiency of at least 85% (p. 3); Achieve an antenna gain of at least 5 dBi (p. 3); Achieve a bandwidth of at least 2.9% of the resonance frequency (p. 3)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the impact of different substrate materials and meshing techniques on antenna performance (p. 7); Investigation of other transparent substrate materials (p. 8)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the designed antenna in Cubesat applications for improved performance and transparency (p. 7); Further optimization of manufacturing processes to reduce error (p. 8)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Microstrip antennas are opaque, preventing solar energy from reaching the Cubesat’s solar cells, thus a transparent microstrip antenna design is required (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a transparent microstrip antenna be designed for GPS L1 band applications in Cubesats? (p. 1); How can a transparent microstrip GPS antenna be designed to meet the desired specifications? (p. 8)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: 3-D radiation pattern with maximum gain in the z-direction (p. 5)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_dim: Patch: 66.4 mm × 66.4 mm, Ground: 95.3 mm × 95.3 mm (p. 4)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Transparent meshed conductor and meshed substrate circularly polarized GPS L1 band microstrip antenna (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT/duroid 5880 (εr = 2.2, tan δ = 0.0004, h = 3.175 mm) (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Coaxial probe feeding point at distance P = 22.77 mm from the left side of the patch (p. 4)

gen.metadata.authors: Ta, L.P.; D.N.; M.H.; Hirose, M.; Not mentioned; Nakayama, D.; L.P. T.
gen.metadata.title: Design of a High-Gain X-Band Electromagnetic Band Gap Microstrip Patch Antenna for CubeSat Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a high-gain, circularly polarized X-band microstrip patch antenna (MPA) using an electromagnetic band gap (EBG) structure for CubeSat applications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Ensure the antenna fits within the 10 cm × 10 cm surface area of a 3U CubeSat (p. 1); Evaluate the antenna performance with 3U CubeSat platforms (p. 16); Achieve gain enhancement using a 16-element ring of EBG structures (p. 16); Form right-hand circular polarization by etching two square slots symmetrically along the right diagonal line of the center radiator (p. 16); Integrate a single EBG ring around a single-element MPA to enhance gain and circular polarization (p. 1); Not mentioned; Maintain a simple and robust design to ensure compatibility with CubeSat standards (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Not mentioned; Investigation of other EBG structures and their impact on antenna performance (p. 1); Study different EBG and metamaterial topologies to further increase the gain (p. 16)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Not mentioned; Use the proposed antenna design for CubeSat applications (p. 16); Further testing and validation in real CubeSat missions (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing a high-gain, circularly polarized X-band microstrip patch antenna (MPA) for CubeSat applications, while maintaining simplicity and robustness (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What is the impact of electromagnetic band-gap (EBG) structures on the antenna's performance? (p. 16); How can the gain of a microstrip patch antenna be enhanced for CubeSat applications? (p. 16); Not mentioned; How can an electromagnetic band gap (EBG) structure be integrated into a single-element MPA to enhance gain and circular polarization while fitting within the size and weight constraints of a CubeSat? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: Anechoic chamber with a pair of X-band helical antennas (p. 12)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Time-domain solver in CST Studio Suite 2019 (p. 6)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms other designs in terms of gain, axial ratio, and bandwidth while maintaining a low profile and simple design (p. 15)
esp.domain_results.return_loss: −21.9 dB (original MPA), −18.2 dB (CP EBG MPA) at 8.483 GHz (p. 6)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_dim: 10 mm × 10 mm (center patch radiator), 10 mm × 10 mm (EBG elements), 2 mm spacing (p. 5)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_siz: Fits within 10 cm × 10 cm surface area of a 3U CubeSat (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: High-gain X-band electromagnetic band gap microstrip patch antenna (p. 1)
